Title: the first pitch insufficiency

Howard: So, how does this game work? I just throw it, like a real ball?
All right.
What’s that about?
The Angels wanted an astronaut to throw out the first pitch, so guess who they called?
Well, a lot of people who weren’t available, but then me.
All right, here we go.
Cut it out. You’re hurting my feelings.
Hey, even professional pitchers need a rubdown after the game.
For your information, I also gave Leonard one hell of a high five.
They’re doing Space Day and NASA asked me. I felt like I couldn’t say no.
Thank you, that would be great.
What’s wrong with the way I run?
Well, I was going to, but the day of tryouts I found my dad’s Playboy collection. Threw my arm out.
Great. You take this and say when to stop. How much further?
How about now?
Are you saying stop and we’re just too far away to hear you?
Are you kidding me?!
There’s no way this is sixty feet.
You realize this isn’t one of those times I want you to exaggerate how long something is.
That’s your help? That’s like saying here’s how you fly a plane, get in the airplane, know where you want to go and fly it.
That was a close one.
Heads up! Watch out!
Hey, Mike. Listen, NASA asked me to throw out the first pitch at an Angels game. You got any advice?
Why shouldn’t I do it?
But it’s for a good cause. What about all the kids that’ll be there?
Well, maybe I’ll do a good job.
Okay, thanks for the pep talk.
Thanks. I’m proud of me, too.
Let’s do it.
Wish me luck.
Thank you. Thank you.

I have a message for the young people here today. When I was asked to throw the first pitch, a little voice in my head said I couldn’t do it. So, I practiced and practiced, and you know what? That little voice was right, but then I remembered that I’m not an athlete. I’m a scientist. So, today’s first pitch will be delivered to home plate by science. Ladies and gentlemen, boys and girls, I present to you a working prototype of the Mars Rover. And here’s the wind-up, and the pitch.
‘Cause I’m an idiot who didn’t think this through.
Okay, while we’re waiting for the ball to arrive, here’s some fun facts about Mars.
Okay, booing isn’t gonna make it go any faster.
Leonard: Yeah, just nice and easy, right over the plate.
Baseball.
He’s practicing.
C’mon now, throw one.
Now you know why we’re not outside.
Oh, that poor waiter.
You don’t even like Yorkshire pudding.
Nice to see a busy couple keep the spark of bureaucracy alive.
You don’t honestly think that, do you?
There isn’t any ranking. And if there were, we wouldn’t be at the bottom of it.
That’s the part you have a problem with?
Okay, I got to, I, I, I, I got to ask. What makes you think that your relationship is so wonderful and ours isn’t?
So do we. And I’ve seen you guys ignore each other for hours doing totally different things.
Yeah, toddlers do that.
You believe this guy? He has to be the best at everything.
Whatever. You can’t even go on a date without checking your relationship agreement.
Some perfect couple. He won’t even share his food with her.
I’m not jealous. I just think it’s silly for you to compare relationships like they’re something that can be quantified.
How ridiculous is he?
Sheldon, you’re just assigning random numbers to things based on your opinion.
So, this is accurate?
Fine. We’ll take it right now.
What?
Why not?
Come on. It’ll be fun.
Sorry.
Are you mad at me?
Um, whew? Is this about the test, or is this about us?
What are you worried about?
Yeah, that scares me, too.
Sometimes.

Okay, well, this might make you feel better. Uh, we’re both scared that our marriage will be a disaster, and so, that’s something that we have in common. Also, we both think I’m not funny. Huh? See, you’re not laughing.
I just want to say one more thing about this. Just because Penny and I are very different people does not mean that we’re a bad couple.
I killed his Chewbacca slippers.
No, no, no, I don’t want to.
Because it doesn’t matter. I don’t care if we’re a ten or a two.
Marriage is scary. You’re scared, I’m scared. But it doesn’t make me not want to do it. It, it just makes me want to hold your hand and do it with you.
This is fun, huh? We get to see our friend throw out the first pitch, have a hot dog, watch the game.
On our Quidditch team, he…
Raj: I’m heckling you. It’s a beloved part of baseball.
So you never played baseball as a kid, not even Little League?
Come on Howard, fire it in.
Is it too late for him to cancel?
Mmm, I love how they put a waterfall at centre field. It really ties the whole stadium together.
Sheldon: He’s right. And given that you’re probably still waiting to be picked for a game that was played in fifth grade, I’m sure you do suck.
Well, not just him. May I remind you that you’re talking to the seeker, beater, chaser and water boy of the third place Griffith Park Quidditch team.
Did you enjoy my lecture?
Well, if you’re going to serve Cornish game hen, you should either be familiar with the history of Cornwall or be prepared to learn it.
Good, I had Cornish game hen.
I missed a number of date nights while I was on my train trip, and I’m contractually obligated to make them up under the terms of the Relationship Agreement.
If you’re free tomorrow night, I’d love to have you join us on a double date.
Oh. Well, then come or don’t. I don’t care.
At our committee meeting, Amy made a motion for a picnic in a park, but I tacked so many amendments on that thing it sank like a lead balloon.
Yeah, which I was initially sceptical of until I saw online that they serve Yorkshire pudding.
No, it’s yucky, but informing people about the history of Yorkshire is yummy, yum-yum.
Ignore them, Amy. They’re just jealous because they’ll never have a relationship as good as ours.
I wasn’t making a joke, I was merely stating fact. Amy and I have a superior relationship to yours.
Leonard, I assumed you knew. The ranking of relationships in our circle by quality is me and Amy, Howard and Bernadette, Raj and his girlfriend, Penny and Chardonnay, Penny and you.
For starters, we enjoy spending time together.
It’s called parallel play.
Not as well as we do.
Oh, listen to them. Not even married and the honeymoon’s over.

If you’ve got a problem basing a relationship on a contract, I’d like to tell you about 13 plucky colonies that entered a relationship agreement called the U.S. Constitution. And it may not be cool to say so, but I think that love affair is still pretty hot today.
May I have one of your fries?
Absolutely not.
It has avocado on it. She’s allergic to avocado. Are you so jealous of our relationship you want Amy to die?
Everything is quantifiable. That French fry? A seven. Spider-Man? A nine. The number nine? Oddly, only a four.
No, I’m not. French fries have three variables, crispiness, saltiness and shape. Which is why a curly fry only gets a two. If I wanted curls for dinner, I’d order a clown wig.
Not according to the work of Berscheid, Snyder and Omoto.
Yeah, not to be confused with the French Fry Goodness Inventory. That’s pure Cooper.
It’s been around for 25 years, and has been extensively corroborated by other researchers.
Kind of? It does it perfectly.
Why? We won. You know, I say, next, we take on Koothrappali and his dog. Really give ourselves a challenge.
The answer is one simple test away. Hmm? You know, it’s like when I thought there was a possum in my closet. Did I sit around wondering? No, I sent Leonard in with a pointy stick and a bag.
Or a one. A one is possible.
We got an eight-point-two. Trust me, you’re happy.
Whoa. Nobody said anything about watching the game.
I expected to see Howard throw the baseball, finish my hot dog, and hightail it across the street to Disneyland just in time for Mickey’s Soundsational Parade.
Who’s the bobblehead of?
No, as long as it bobbles.
Okay, new plan. We go to Disneyland, play hide and seek on Tom Sawyer’s Island, and then come back and see the end of the pitch.
He makes a valid point.
Penny: Hi. What’s going on?
Okay, this is not what I meant when I said go outside and play.
For what?
What, you? Really?
That’s so cool. Congratulations. I guess that makes you the athlete of the group.
I know. Watching your boyfriend run around with a broomstick between his legs isn’t something you forget.
Hey, how was dinner?
You guys are going out two nights in a row?
That’s so hot.
Aw.
Sheldon, I’m surprised you’d choose to go to a pub.
Isn’t this when he says bazooka or something?
Yeah, and actually, I drink Sauvignon Blanc.
Relax.
So what? Why do you even care?
Uh, we’re not sure. But I want to wait long enough to prove to my mother I’m not pregnant.
A hundred.
Well, a relationship is more complicated than a French fry.
Oh, what did those rascals do now?
Well, kind of takes the romance out of relationships.
No, don’t.
Just don’t take it.
‘Cause it’s stupid. Who cares what number it is?
I said I don’t want you to. I’m getting another drink.
No, stop being stupid.
Look, I don’t need a score on a test to make me worry about something I’m already worried about.
That we’re engaged and have nothing in common, and it scares me.
It does?
Well, that’s not good. You being blindly infatuated with me was the rock we were building this relationship on.
Hey, sorry about that.
Let’s just take the test.
Oh, well, ’cause you know we’re gonna do bad.
Leonard.
Look at you, talking sports.
Can he really throw a ball?
Yeah, that’s a no.
Amy: No, and neither did our waiter.
It’s hard to argue with that. And I know because I saw a sad man with a pepper mill desperately try and fail.
Sheldon, how about tomorrow night we see a movie?
It’s better than hot, it’s binding.
You are aware that a double date doesn’t count as two dates.
After a lively debate, that proposal passed by a two-zero margin.
There they go, fighting again. You’d never hear her talk that way to Sauvignon Blanc.
It’s a good thing I’m not wearing flag underwear right now, ’cause there’s about to be a fire.
So when do you guys plan on getting married?
Of course. Can I have a bite of your burger?
They developed the Relationship Closeness Inventory, which predicts the stability of a couple based on behaviour.
Sheldon and I got an eight-point-two out of ten.
I’m gonna let you count this as two dates. They’re a lot of work.
No, we’re sorry. We never should have been comparing relationships in the first place.
It would make me so happy if you said things like that.
I’ll tell you what. If we stay, I’ll buy you cotton candy and a bobblehead.
Bernadette: But they throw an actual ball. You were throwing air at a TV.
I’m kind of surprised you agreed to do this in front of a stadium full of people.
Okay. Well, if you want, I could help you practice. I played a lot of softball growing up.
Great. And while we’re at it, maybe we could butch up your run for when you head out to the mound.
All right, the pitcher’s mound in Major League Baseball is sixty feet, six inches away from home plate.
Okay, it’s not that hard. You just look to where you want to throw it, step towards where you want to throw, and throw it.
Just throw the ball. Let’s see what we’re working with.
Howie, I am so proud of you.
Why is it going so slow?
Mike: Yeah. Don’t do it. What else you up to?
There’s no upside. If you do well, no one cares. And if you screw up, you’re an idiot on YouTube forever.
That’s what I’m telling you. Kids are the worst. My own daughter tweeted I have a giant nose.
I don’t know. In space, you couldn’t even toss me a pen, and that was in zero gravity.
Anytime, Froot Loops. Give your wife a hug for me. She’s so much cuter than you, I don’t know how you ever got her.
